title: Carson County
text:
Import
Import the excel sheet

carson <- read_excel("data-raw/CarsonCounty.xlsx", col_types = c("date","guess","guess","date", "guess", "guess", "guess", "guess", "skip"))

Warning: Expecting date in D15 / R15C4: got '9.:40'

Warning: Coercing numeric to date in D657 / R657C4

carson



  



I had to import the data with col_types described so that the date and time didn’t mess up badly.
Now I want to combine the date and time into one column and make it Dttm.

title: Carson County
text:
Rearranging Columns

carson_col <- carson |> mutate(
  datetime_arrest = paste(date_arrest, paste(hour(time_arrest), minute(time_arrest), second(time_arrest), sep = ":")))

carson_clean <- carson_col |> mutate(
  datetime_arrest = ymd_hms(datetime_arrest)
) |> select(
  -time_arrest
) |> cbind(agency_arrest = NA, ethnicity = NA)

title: Randall County
text:
Clean
Get rid of extra columns and make date_arrest and time_arrest into one column.

randall_clean <- randall |> mutate(
  datetime_arrest = paste(date_arrest,substr(time_arrest,12,19)),
  datetime_arrest = ymd_hms(datetime_arrest),
) |> select(
  -"SO #",
  -time_arrest,
  -agency_arrest,
  -warrant_ref,
  -height_ft,
  -height_in,
  -weight,
  -address
) |> cbind(address_arrest = NA, agency_arrest = NA, ethnicity = NA)

title: Amarillo City
text:
Import Excel Sheet
First, we will start with Amarillo City data to test out the process.

amarillo <- read_excel("data-raw/AmarilloCity.xlsx")

amarillo



  



It worked! read_excel() is the best!

title: Amarillo City
text:
Clean up columns
Now I want to clean up the columns so the date and times are separate and there is no extra columns. First change the date/time to a date type.

amarillo_date <- amarillo |> mutate (
  datetime_arrest = mdy_hm(datetime_arrest)
)

amarillo_date |> glimpse()

Rows: 649
Columns: 5
$ `Incident #s`   <chr> "20220521758", "20220521183", "20220521123", "20220521…
$ datetime_arrest <dttm> 2022-12-21 15:39:00, 2022-12-16 18:37:00, 2022-12-11 …
$ name            <chr> "GUEVARA, LAURA", "TOLER, NICHOLAS DON", "CARRILLO SAL…
$ charges         <chr> "POSS MARIJ < 2OZDRUG PARA-POSS CL C", "WARRANT-HOLD F…
$ address_arrest  <chr> "7200 SW 34TH AVE, AMAR", "SE 10TH AVE / ROSS ST, AMAR…


Done!
Now I want to get rid of the Incident #’s column and make the date and time separate columns.

amarillo_clean <- amarillo_date |>  mutate(
  date_arrest = date(datetime_arrest)) |> select(
  -'Incident #s') |> cbind(
    age = NA, race = NA, sex = NA, agency_arrest = NA,  ethnicity = NA)

amarillo_clean |> glimpse()

Rows: 649
Columns: 10
$ datetime_arrest <dttm> 2022-12-21 15:39:00, 2022-12-16 18:37:00, 2022-12-11 …
$ name            <chr> "GUEVARA, LAURA", "TOLER, NICHOLAS DON", "CARRILLO SAL…
$ charges         <chr> "POSS MARIJ < 2OZDRUG PARA-POSS CL C", "WARRANT-HOLD F…
$ address_arrest  <chr> "7200 SW 34TH AVE, AMAR", "SE 10TH AVE / ROSS ST, AMAR…
$ date_arrest     <date> 2022-12-21, 2022-12-16, 2022-12-11, 2022-12-10, 2022-…
$ age             <lgl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA…
$ race            <lgl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA…
$ sex             <lgl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA…
$ agency_arrest   <lgl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA…
$ ethnicity       <lgl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA…


How do I get the date separated??? Try pasting the separate pieces together.

title: Analysis v2
text:
Import and Combine
We will use list.files(), map() and list_rbind() to import and combine our files in one fell swoop.
First I am making a list of all my files from the data processed folder.

wx_files_list <- list.files(
  "data-processed",
  pattern = "\\.csv",
  full.names = TRUE
)

wx_files_list

 [1] "data-processed/Amarillo-City.csv"  "data-processed/Carson-County.csv" 
 [3] "data-processed/Howard-County.csv"  "data-processed/Lubbock-County.csv"
 [5] "data-processed/Midland-City.csv"   "data-processed/Monahans-City.csv" 
 [7] "data-processed/Moore-County.csv"   "data-processed/Nolan-County.csv"  
 [9] "data-processed/Odessa-City.csv"    "data-processed/Pecos-City.csv"    
[11] "data-processed/Plainview-City.csv" "data-processed/Randall-County.csv"
[13] "data-processed/Slaton-City.csv"    "data-processed/Snyder-City.csv"   
[15] "data-processed/Wheeler-County.csv"


Now I am going to combine all the files into one tibble using rbind.

wx_all <- wx_files_list |> 
  set_names(basename) |> #what does this do?
  map(
  read_csv, 
  col_select = c(name, charges, address_arrest, age, race, sex, agency_arrest, date_arrest, ethnicity)
  )|> 
    list_rbind(names_to = "source") |> #names_to gives me a column with the source file so I can parse it later
    clean_names()

Now I am going to break up the source column so I have a column with the city or county name and if it’s a city or county, and I will make the date_arrest column a date type.

all_data <- wx_all |> mutate(
  city_county_name = str_split_i(source, "-", 1),
  city_county1 = str_split_i(source,"-", -1),
  city_county = if_else(city_county1 == "City.csv", "City", "County"),
  date_arrest = date(date_arrest)
  ) |> select(-city_county1, -source)

all_data

title: Analysis v2
text:
Analysis
Now we get to do the analysis of all the data together. First, I am going to group by each month.

all_data_month <- all_data |> group_by(month = floor_date(date_arrest, 'month')) |> 
  summarize(arrests = n())

all_data_month



  



Now I want to graph this.

all_data_month |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = month, y = arrests)) +
  geom_point() 

Warning: Removed 1 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).






all_data_region <- all_data |> group_by(city_county_name, date_arrest) |> 
  summarize(arrests = n())

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'city_county_name'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.

all_data_region



  




all_data_region |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = date_arrest, y = arrests)) +
  geom_point(size = 0.25) +
  ylim(0,20) +
  facet_wrap(~city_county_name)

Warning: Removed 5 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).
